awd_titl_txt: Modernizing Agriculture Technician Education in Appalachian Northeast Georgia
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to address the growing need for agricultural technicians in Northeast Georgia.  The agriculture industry is increasingly driven by precision technologies that maximize productivity and minimize waste and environmental hazards. These processes require advanced mechanization and global navigation satellite systems for implementation. To prepare agricultural technicians for work in precision technologies, the project will develop two agriculture technology programs that are aligned to local agricultural industry needs.  These programs will be designed so that students can develop both technical and higher order competencies and industry-supported credentials.  With these skills and credentials, the students will be able to enter the agricultural technician workforce at middle-skilled levels. This project aims to increase the skilled technical workforce in Northeast Georgia, thus increasing the ability of employers to recruit skilled agricultural technicians locally. 

The project plans to develop two new academic programs that can prepare students for technical work in modern agricultural industries: Agribusiness; and Modern Diversified Agriculture. Two complementary goals will be pursued. The first is to develop experiential, diversified curricula specific to the needs of the local agriculture industry. The second is to recruit and retain Appalachian students in these agricultural technician programs. The curricula will be designed through a partnership with the agriculture industry and local agriculture advisory committee members.  The curricula will focus on providing students with hands-on opportunities in the context of learning laboratories. The project will engage a pool of student who are largely untapped due to a lack of awareness of the available positions and a lack of access to the technical education needed to fill the positions. Information in the project annual evaluation reports will be used to measure project success, to adjust strategies, and to inform stakeholders about project progress. The project will also investigate how the community, through its higher education institutions, can engage the agriculture industry and Appalachian families and students in preparing agriculture technicians for well-paying, local jobs. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project responded to the growing demand for agriculture (ag) technicians in rural Appalachian Northeast Georgia and discovered how the community, through its colleges, can engage the ag industry and Appalachian families and students in developing ag technicians and breaking the generational poverty cycle. The two goals were: 1) Develop experiential diversified curricula specific to the Northeast Georgia’s ag industry needs, and 2) Recruit and retain Appalachian students for North Georgia Technical College’s ag programs. The objectives were to create and implement curricula for the Agribusiness and Modern Diversified Agriculture programs; form five collaborations with ag employers to provide pre-professional experiences for ag students; recruit 30 new students by collaborating with six family organizations; and achieve a retention rate of 70% Fall Semester to Fall Semester for the ag programs.

The external evaluator reported the project met both goals and experienced success with program objectives despite a global viral pandemic and transitions in project and institutional leadership. The project completed all four proposed curricula (Agribusiness Marketing, Livestock & Poultry Production & Management, Precision Agriculture, and Principles of Agronomy) and a lab manual (Aquaculture). According to the evaluator, the 69 industry collaborations were key to the program. They provided their time through meetings and collaborative support to help develop appropriate course curricula as well as laboratory and authentic experiences. They are a key component of agriculture curricula development at NGTC providing expertise regarding industry needs for now and in the future.

Collaborations with 12 ag-related  family organizations (e.g., FFA, Young Farmers, Parent University) and 11 school systems resulted in 61 new students enrolling in the program during the grant term. The program retained 63% of the students (excluding Cohort 5, who enrolled in Fall Semester 2024 during the final two months of the grant term).

Though not a metric for Goal 2, thus far 10 students graduated from the program sooner than expected during the grant term: 90% of the graduates resided in Appalachia, 50% were First-Generation College Students (i.e., parents did not attend or complete college before the student’s 18th birthday), and 40% received needs-based financial aid.

The intellectual merit and the broad impact of this project are vast. While the students were intrigued by the bells and whistles of the Precision Ag course, they quickly saw the role that technology plays in soil management and crop production (i.e., agronomy), livestock production and management, and agribusiness management. Equipped with a new fleet of uncrewed aerial systems (UAS or DRONES) and sensors, students were empowered to learn sciences and data applications on the cutting-edge of precision ag and share their knowledge with the local ag industry. For example, few local farmers and ranchers previously understood how UAS could improve their decision-making and operating costs in relation to forage nutrition. Although they knew the importance of forage nutrition; they had no knowledge of the actual nutrition in the hay they are using. Using precision ag instruments, students conducted soil monitoring, multispectral imaging, and physical sample testing at local farms and ranches. Sharing the results and findings with the farmers and ranchers, the students engaged them in discussions about soil amendments and forage diversity to increase nutritional quality for their livestock and how precision ag technology can improve their operations by increasing profits and reduce field labor input. Through word of mouth by these satisfied farmers and ranchers and community awareness events (e.g., ag conferences, cattlemen’s associations, FFAs), the Project Team received more requests for the students to provide precision ag demonstrations. Another type of industry request is for student applied research projects (e.g., thermal tracking of aphid infestation using robotic dual cameras with thermal imaging sensors).

Though these requests primarily deal with the potential for use of technology in agronomic practices and/or livestock production and management, it demonstrates that hands-on pre-professional experiences are critical in actively engaging students and encouraging them to persist and complete their ag college education. Furthermore, these experiences strengthen the Appalachian values of localism (sense of belonging and of being a part of the land) and historicism (sense of understanding one’s place and history within the region). According to the evaluator, 23 (38%) of the 61 students were First-Generation College Students without a family role model to provide college advice and guidance. For this reason, faculty must be seen as playing a vital role in the students’ career decisions.

The evaluator concluded that the “success of this program reflects the reflexibility and resiliency of the faculty, staff, and students of NGTC and the successful partners they worked with to guide the program. The NGTC Agriculture Program is affecting Northeast Georgia’s agriculture industry in a positive way. It will also provide opportunities for children of Appalachia to grow and succeed in an agricultural community in a way that did not previously exist for them.”

 


Last Modified: 01/22/2025
Modified by: Russell J Logan

The two goals were: 1) Develop experiential diversified curricula specific to the Northeast Georgias ag industry needs, and 2) Recruit and retain Appalachian students for North Georgia Technical Colleges ag programs. The program retained 63% of the students (excluding Cohort 5, who enrolled in Fall Semester 2024 during the final two months of the grant term).


Though not a metric for Goal 2, thus far 10 students graduated from the program sooner than expected during the grant term: 90% of the graduates resided in Appalachia, 50% were First-Generation College Students (i.e., parents did not attend or complete college before the students 18th birthday), and 40% received needs-based financial aid.

Though these requests primarily deal with the potential for use of technology in agronomic practices and/or livestock production and management, it demonstrates that hands-on pre-professional experiences are critical in actively engaging students and encouraging them to persist and complete their ag college education.
